title: Error Detection and Recovery
content: Prevention can't catch all errors—detection and recovery are equally important. Systems need redundancy, verification points, and recovery capability. Catching errors before consequences matters as much as preventing them initially.

mcq.question: An error is made but caught and corrected before any consequence. How should this be treated?

options.B: Valuable learning opportunity about what enabled both the error and the catch
options.C: Discipline the person who made the error
options.D: Credit only to whoever caught it

mcq.explanation: Near-misses are gifts—they reveal error-prone conditions without consequences. Understanding what enabled the error helps prevention; understanding what enabled the catch helps build detection capability. Both are valuable.

openQuestions: How does your organization treat near-misses?
What systems help you catch errors before consequences?
